commands.name: archive
commands.description: Create an archive of this composer package
commands.help:
The <info>archive</info> command creates an archive of the specified format
containing the files and directories of the Composer project or the specified
package in the specified version and writes it to the specified directory.

<info>php composer.phar archive [--format=zip] [--dir=/foo] [package [version]]</info>

package.name: package
package.description: The package to archive instead of the current project

version.name: version
version.description: A version constraint to find the package to archive

format.name: --format
format.description: Format of the resulting archive: tar or zip

dir.name: --dir
dir.description: Write the archive to this directory

file.name: --file
file.description: Write the archive with the given file name. Note that the format will be appended.

commands.name: browse
commands.description: Opens the package's repository URL or homepage in your browser.
commands.help:
The home command opens or shows a package's repository URL or
homepage in your default browser.

To open the homepage by default, use -H or --homepage.
To show instead of open the repository or homepage URL, use -s or --show.

homepage.description: Open the homepage instead of the repository URL.

show.name: --show
show.description: Only show the homepage or repository URL.

commands.name: config
commands.description: Set config options
commands.help:
This command allows you to edit some basic composer settings in either the
local composer.json file or the global config.json file.

To set a config setting:

    <comment>vendor/bin/composer config bin-dir bin/</comment>

To read a config setting:

    <comment>vendor/bin/composer config bin-dir</comment>
    Outputs: <info>bin</info>

To edit the global config.json file:

    <comment>vendor/bin/composer config --global</comment>

To add a repository:

    <comment>vendor/bin/composer config repositories.foo vcs https://bar.com</comment>

To remove a repository (repo is a short alias for repositories):

    <comment>vendor/bin/composer config --unset repo.foo</comment>

To disable packagist:

    <comment>vendor/bin/composer config repo.packagist false</comment>

You can alter repositories in the global config.json file by passing in the
<info>--global</info> option.

To edit the file in an external editor:

    <comment>vendor/bin/composer config --editor</comment>

To choose your editor you can set the "EDITOR" env variable.

To get a list of configuration values in the file:

    <comment>vendor/bin/composer config --list</comment>

You can always pass more than one option. As an example, if you want to edit the
global config.json file.

    <comment>vendor/bin/composer config --editor --global</comment>

global.name: --global
global.description: Apply command to the global config file

auth.name: --auth
auth.description: Affect auth config file (only used for --editor)

file.name: --file
file.description: If you want to choose a different composer.json or config.json

absolute.name: --absolute
absolute.description: Returns absolute paths when fetching *-dir config values instead of relative

commands.name: create-project
commands.description: Create new project from a package into given directory.
commands.help:
The <info>create-project</info> command creates a new project from a given
package into a new directory. If executed without params and in a directory
with a composer.json file it installs the packages for the current project.

You can use this command to bootstrap new projects or setup a clean
version-controlled installation for developers of your project.

<info>php composer.phar create-project vendor/project target-directory [version]</info>

You can also specify the version with the package name using = or : as separator.

<info>php composer.phar create-project vendor/project:version target-directory</info>

To install unstable packages, either specify the version you want, or use the
--stability=dev (where dev can be one of RC, beta, alpha or dev).

To setup a developer workable version you should create the project using the source
controlled code by appending the <info>'--prefer-source'</info> flag.

To install a package from another repository than the default one you
can pass the <info>'--repository=https://myrepository.org'</info> flag.

directory.name: directory
directory.description: Directory where the files should be created

stability.name: --stability
stability.description: Minimum-stability allowed (unless a version is specified).

prefer-source.name: --prefer-source
prefer-source.description: Forces installation from package sources when possible, including VCS information.

prefer-dist.name: --prefer-dist
prefer-dist.description: Forces installation from package dist even for dev versions.

repository.name: --repository
repository.description: Pick a different repository (as url or json config) to look for the package.

dev.name: --dev
dev.description: Enables installation of require-dev packages (enabled by default, only present for BC).

keep-vcs.name: --keep-vcs
keep-vcs.description: Whether to prevent deletion vcs folder.

no-install.name: --no-install
no-install.description: Whether to skip installation of the package dependencies.

commands.name: global
commands.description: Allows running commands in the global composer dir ($COMPOSER_HOME).
commands.help:
Use this command as a wrapper to run other Composer commands
within the global context of COMPOSER_HOME.

You can use this to install CLI utilities globally, all you need
is to add the COMPOSER_HOME/vendor/bin dir to your PATH env var.

COMPOSER_HOME is c:\Users\<user>\AppData\Roaming\Composer on Windows
and /home/<user>/.composer on unix systems.

Note: This path may vary depending on customizations to bin-dir in
composer.json or the environmental variable COMPOSER_BIN_DIR.

commands.name: help
commands.description: Displays help for a command
commands.help:
The <info>help</info> command displays help for a given command:

  <info>php vendor/bin/composer help list</info>

You can also output the help in other formats by using the <comment>--format</comment> option:

  <info>php vendor/bin/composer help --format=xml list</info>

To display the list of available commands, please use the <info>list</info> command.

commands.name: install
commands.description: Installs the project dependencies from the composer.lock file if present, or falls back on the composer.json.
commands.help:
The <info>install</info> command reads the composer.lock file from
the current directory, processes it, and downloads and installs all the
libraries and dependencies outlined in that file. If the file does not
exist it will look for composer.json and do the same.

<info>php composer.phar install</info>

commands.name: list
commands.description: Lists commands
commands.help:
The <info>list</info> command lists all commands:

  <info>php vendor/bin/composer list</info>

You can also display the commands for a specific namespace:

  <info>php vendor/bin/composer list test</info>

You can also output the information in other formats by using the <comment>--format</comment> option:

  <info>php vendor/bin/composer list --format=xml</info>

It's also possible to get raw list of commands (useful for embedding command runner):

  <info>php vendor/bin/composer list --raw</info>

commands.name: require
commands.description: Adds required packages to your composer.json and installs them
commands.help:
The require command adds required packages to your composer.json and installs them.

If you do not specify a version constraint, composer will choose a suitable one based on the available package versions.

If you do not want to install the new dependencies immediately you can call it with --no-update

commands.name: update
commands.description: Updates your dependencies to the latest version according to composer.json, and updates the composer.lock file.
commands.help:
The <info>update</info> command reads the composer.json file from the
current directory, processes it, and updates, removes or installs all the
dependencies.

<info>php composer.phar update</info>

To limit the update operation to a few packages, you can list the package(s)
you want to update as such:

<info>php composer.phar update vendor/package1 foo/mypackage [...]</info>

You may also use an asterisk (*) pattern to limit the update operation to package(s)
from a specific vendor:

<info>php composer.phar update vendor/package1 foo/* [...]</info>

To select packages names interactively with auto-completion use <info>-i</info>.

packages.name: packages
packages.description: Packages that should be updated, if not provided all packages are.

prefer-source.name: --prefer-source
prefer-source.description: Forces installation from package sources when possible, including VCS information.

prefer-dist.name: --prefer-dist
prefer-dist.description: Forces installation from package dist even for dev versions.

dry-run.name: --dry-run
dry-run.description: Outputs the operations but will not execute anything (implicitly enables --verbose).

dev.name: --dev
dev.description: Enables installation of require-dev packages (enabled by default, only present for BC).

lock.name: --lock
lock.description: Only updates the lock file hash to suppress warning about the lock file being out of date.

no-scripts.name: --no-scripts
no-scripts.description: Skips the execution of all scripts defined in composer.json file.

with-dependencies.name: --with-dependencies
with-dependencies.description: Add also all dependencies of whitelisted packages to the whitelist.

root-reqs.description: Restricts the update to your first degree dependencies.

no-interaction.description: Do not ask any interactive question

profile.description: Display timing and memory usage information

working-dir.description: If specified, use the given directory as working directory.

commands.name: validate
commands.description: Validates a composer.json and composer.lock
commands.help:
The validate command validates a given composer.json and composer.lock

Exit codes in case of errors are:
1 validation warning(s), only when --strict is given
2 validation error(s)
3 file unreadable or missing

no-check-all.name: --no-check-all
no-check-all.description: Do not make a complete validation

no-check-lock.name: --no-check-lock
no-check-lock.description: Do not check if lock file is up to date

no-check-publish.name: --no-check-publish
no-check-publish.description: Do not check for publish errors

with-dependencies.name: --with-dependencies
with-dependencies.description: Also validate the composer.json of all installed dependencies

strict.name: --strict
strict.description: Return a non-zero exit code for warnings as well as errors

verbose.description: Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug

no-interaction.description: Do not ask any interactive question

profile.description: Display timing and memory usage information

working-dir.description: If specified, use the given directory as working directory.
